content:
Cool idea, but quite hard under time pressure of a clash in its current form.

I just got it in Shortest mode and won with 60%, no one else got above 0%. It was a lot harder than it looked. I was close at the end, but had some bugs still.

It would be good to note in the constraints that the missing piece will never be a corner, because that allows for some much simpler solutions to be coded just looking at rows and columns for "#.#" to occur.

In the clash I could see the tests had no corners, but wasn't sure if the validators would so wasted time deciding which way I was going to code it.

If you make it clear that the missing piece will always look like "#.#" either horizontally or vertically, then it becomes a lot more clash-friendly. It's giving away the trick in some sense, but currently I think it's just a bit too daunting without clarification of the limits of the missing piece.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash, many ways to solve it and with no tests for edge cases so nothing to worry about (missing fence corners, invalid characters in map, fence impossible to close, several fences, etc). Perfect for clash! ðŸ‘¾

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice work! Reading the description I was a bit worried that it might be too difficult, but I took a very simple approach assuming that there was a single hole in one of the sides of the fence and that worked for all test cases.
In my opinion this looks a bit hard to reverse, especially since the coordinates in the output are flipped compared to the standard way of writing it

I think you can make it more tricky by adding a test case, like this:
4
7
###o###
#ooooc#
###o###
1 4
(I used 'o' instead of '.' so it appears well aligned in the comments)
Not sure if this is suitable to be in your contribution.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is easily comprehensible for most people and solvable in the available time for a clash of code

The most important thing to understand is that the fence is a rectangle, it may be useful to make it more visible (bold ?).

It seems to me that the max length of the rows is missing, should be a parameter of the input
Line 1 : n, number of lines
Line 2 : l, length of the lines
Next n lines : rows

Could you put the constraints in the puzzle :
0 < n < ?
0 < l < ?

Great puzzle :)

Thanks, glad you like it and also glad with your feedback!
- I made the rectangle part bold.
- I put in the statement 'A pasture of length [[l]] and width [[w]]', and introduced [[w]] in the input (and turned former [[n]] into [[l]].
- I included the constraint (it should be at least 3, because otherwise there cannot be a fence with a cow inside :-)).

Ah that's definitely more tricky. I played with the idea of non-rectangular, but not yet with this one (redundant fence). Let me think about it for a moment / see whether I can come up with a 5min solution. At the moment I suspect it might make it beyond clash size.

EDIT: thought about it, and while I like the idea I do not dare put it in this clash. Such a test case obviously would come as one of the later cases, so I think quite some players will spend the first couple of minutes on writing a solution assuming there is only a rectangle fence (my solution for example lazily checks simply the outer-most #'s, and assumes the fence must be there). The case you propose would require a quite different approach; in my situation I would have written a full solution with some debugging in the first 5 min, then suddenly run into this case and have to write a totally different solution.

I am not sure whether they are 'flipped compared to standard'; it is indeed not x->y (common for geographics), but it is row->column (common for numpy array slicing at least).

I'll stick to this format for now; the benefit reverse players have is that they see all the cases at the same time, and once they connect the missing # to location already from the first case it is clear it must be row->column. However thanks for the feedback, and if any other players feel like you, I will think about a change to make it easier for reverse players.

Thanks! During play others like you assumed that it might be more difficult, and it resulted for them in not being able to solve the clash (see comments above), so I had to add some constraints to more explicitly tell players that they only need to code for one hole in the fence. Because, indeed, my goal was that a simple approach should be sufficient.

Thanks! I just added two constraints, based on the feedback of @StepBack13, to explicitly keep a couple of edge cases out, because indeed the intention was to keep it easy. I forgot that some players might assume it would be more difficult.

PS just fixed my code in the IDE and it was a 1 character fix to get 100%, haha. I just ran out of time in the clash.

If you just add something like this to constraints I think this would be a lot easier for clashers to tackle:

Missing piece will always be a single piece ({{#.#}}) and never a corner.

Thanks for taking your time to share your feedback! To keep it clash size I did not include any edge cases, but I overlooked that non-reverse players might assume some possible edge cases. 
I added two constraints (only one piece is missing, it is never a corner).
No worries, glad to see it updated, it's a fun clash now it's more clear. :)

Thank you, seems good to me ! :)
(as this is wip, we cannot for the moment approve the puzzle, but maybe other people would have something to say)
I just put it in Ready - I think the Clash is quite straightforward, so for me not much Work In Progress to do after your relevant suggestions.
